field_label: Record ID

The Second Health and Wellness Questionnaire (Q2) is the next step in the Football Players Health Study at Harvard
University and is important for understanding changes in the health of former professional football players over time. We invite you to continue to participate in this important study by filling out the questionnaire on the following pages.
Please click 'Next Page' below to advance to the first part of the survey. There are five sections of the survey - demographic information and playing history, cardiovascular health,
neurocognitive health, pain, and other outcomes. Once you complete a section and hit 'Next Page', you will
not be able to return to that section. Please review your answers before submitting them. In total, the questionnaire takes between 30-45 minutes to fill out. You may hit the 'Save & Return Later' button at the
bottom of each page at any time if you cannot complete the questionnaire in a single sitting. You will be given a return
code for your survey. Please keep this code in a safe place. If you lose your code, you may restart the survey or you
may contact our study team at players@footballplayershealth.harvard.edu or at 617-432-5000 to retrieve your code. The preferred platform for taking this survey is a desktop or laptop computer, or a tablet with an external keyboard.
You may also use a smartphone, though it may be more difficult for you to enter your answers. Thank you for your continued support of the Football Players Health Study, and please do not hesitate to reach out to
the team with any questions. Sincerely, Marc Weisskopf, ScD, PhD Director of Epidemiological Studies, Football Players Health Study Professor, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

section_header: <font size = 4>Permission to Take Part in a Human Research Study</font>
field_label:
Key Information The following is a short summary of this study to help you decide whether to participate. More detailed information is listed later on in this form.
Why am I being invited to take part in a questionnaire for the Football Players Health Study? We have invited you to take part in a research study because you are eligible for the second health and wellness
questionnaire (Q2) as part of the Football Players Health Study at Harvard University ('the Study'). You completed
the first health and wellness questionnaire (Q1) and are being invited to complete additional surveys in order to assess health over time. We are inviting all former NFL players who completed Q1 to complete additional questionnaires as
part of a longitudinal cohort study. These questionnaires capture basic health information from former professional
football players like you and enables our study team to build a foundation of knowledge on former player health.
Responses from the first questionnaire informed the development of Q2 and the direction of the study's research. What should I know about the Football Players Health Study?
  • You may contact the study team of the Football Players Health Study if you have any questions.
  • Whether you participate in the Study is up to you.
  • You can choose not to take part in the Study.
  • You can agree to take part and later change your mind.
  • Your decision will not be held against you and will not affect your medical treatment or any outside litigation.
  • You may discuss your decision with your family, your friends and/or your doctor.
  • You can ask all the questions you want before you decide.
Why is this research being done? This research is being done to better understand how playing football can affect the health status of former players.
With as many participants as possible, we can gather data about the health conditions most common and most
important to former players like yourself and use that information to direct the future research questions of the study. How long will I take part in this research? Q2 should take 30-40 minutes but may depend on how quickly you read and answer questions. You may exit the
survey and return to complete it at a later time. You will be given a survey return code, and you may contact the study
team if you lose your return code. You may be contacted to complete follow-up questionnaires as part of the Football Players Health Study at Harvard University. As part of the questionnaire(s), you will be asked to complete a series of questions aiming to understand your current
state of health and well-being and your health history. The questionnaire(s) may also ask about your professional
football experience and changes in your health, thinking, and lifestyle. You may answer or skip any questions you
would like. More detailed information about the study procedures can be found under the "What can I expect if I take part in this research?" section. Is there any way being in this study could be bad for me? As with any collection of data, there is a potential for loss of privacy and confidentiality. We will take all reasonable
steps to protect the privacy of the study participants. It is also possible that some of the questions may cause
discomfort or emotional distress. We have included more detail about these steps below in the "What are the risks
and possible discomforts?" section. Will being in this study help me in any way? There are no direct benefits to you from your participation in this research. We cannot promise any benefits to others
from your participation in this research. However, by giving us a better understanding of your life and health status, it
is the starting point for developing follow-up studies to assess various health problems of former players in more detail.
We hope that this work will lead to earlier interventions for football-related health problems, minimize long-term health problems, and lead to a better quality of life for former players, as well as for future generations of players. What happens if I do not want to be in this research? Participation in research is completely voluntary. You can decide to participate or not to participate. Your alternative to participating in this research study is to not participate.
Detailed Information
To follow, please find more detailed information about this study than already provided above. About this consent form Please read this form carefully. It provides important information about participating in research. You have the right to
take your time in making decisions about participating in this research. If you have any questions about the research
or any portion of this form, you may contact the study team. If you decide to participate in this research, you will be
asked to keep a copy of this form for your records. Who can I talk to? If you have questions, concerns, or complaints, talk to the research team at 617-432-5000 or players@footballplayershealth.harvard.edu. This research has been reviewed by the Harvard Longwood Medical Area Institutional Review Board (IRB). If you
wish to speak with someone from the IRB, you may contact the Office of Human Research Administration (OHRA)
at 617-432-2157 (or toll-free at 1-866-606-0573) or at irb@hsph.harvard.edu for any of the following:
  • If your questions, concerns, or complaints are not being answered by the research team,
  • If you cannot reach the research team,
  • If you want to talk to someone besides the research team,
  • If you have questions about your rights as a research participant, or
  • If you want to get information or provide input about this research.
Participation is voluntaryYou are invited to take part in this research because you are a former NFL player. It is your choice whether or not to participate. If you choose to participate, you may change your mind and leave the study at
any time. Refusal to participate or stopping your participation will involve no penalty or loss of benefits to which you
are otherwise entitled. How many people will take part in this research? About 4,000 people will take part in this research. What can I expect if I take part in this research? As a participant, you will be expected to complete questionnaires as part of the longitudinal study. What are the risks and possible discomforts? The risks may include loss of privacy and confidentiality, and as such, the Study takes extensive steps to protect your information, as detailed below in the section 'If I take part in this research, how will my privacy be protected?' Additionally, some of the questions may cause discomfort or emotional distress. If you encounter any of these feelings, please contact the NFL LifeLine at 1-800-506-0078, a confidential resource for current and former NFL players and
their families, or the Football Players Health Study team at 617-432-5000. The study team may be able to answer any questions you have about the research or can refer you to additional resources for support. Are there any benefits from being in this research study? There are no direct benefits to you from your participation in this research. We cannot promise any benefits to others
from your participation in this research. However, by giving us a better understanding of your life and health status, it
is the starting point for developing follow-up studies to assess various health problems of former players in more detail.
We hope that this work will lead to earlier interventions for football-related health problems, minimize long-term health problems, and lead to a better quality of life for former players, as well as for future generations of players. What happens if I say yes, but I change my mind later? You can leave the research at any time it will not be held against you. Will I be compensated for participating in this research? You will not be compensated for your participation in this research, but after completing the survey, you will have the chance to enter a drawing for one of several $100 gift cards. What will I have to pay for if I participate in this research? It will not cost you anything to participate in this research. If I take part in this research, how will my privacy be protected? What happens to the information you collect? Efforts will be made to limit the use and disclosure of your personal information, including research study and medical records, to people who have a need to review this information. We cannot promise complete secrecy. Organizations
that may inspect and copy your information include the IRB. We have taken the following additional precautions:

  • The questionnaire responses will not include your name.
  • Questionnaire responses are identified by a unique code only identifiable to the researchers.
  • We will store your information in a secure database. Only a limited number of people will have access to this database. Our team is trained to handle highly confidential data.
  • We will not identify you in any publication or presentation without your permission.
  • We have obtained a Certificate of Confidentiality issued by the National Institutes of Health of the U.S.
    Department of Health and Human Services
This research is covered by a Certificate of Confidentiality from the National Institutes of Health. This adds special protection
for the research information that may identify you. The researchers may not disclose information that may identify you,
even under a court order or subpoena, unless you give permission. However, a Certificate of Confidentiality does not prevent researchers from disclosing your information if required by law
(such as to report child or elder abuse, communicable diseases or harm to self or others); if you have consented (agreed) to
the disclosure (such as for your medical treatment); or for use in other research as allowed by law. The Certificate does not stop you from voluntarily releasing information about yourself or your involvement
in this research. However, to more fully protect your confidentiality, it may be better
to state that you support the Football Players Health Study in general terms, rather than making
specific statements like, "I have completed the Football Players Health Study questionnaire." If you want your research information released to anyone not connected with the research, you must provide consent
to allow the researchers to release it. If others obtain your written consent to receive research information, then the
researchers are permitted, but not necessarily required to disclose that information. Can I be removed from the research without my OK? The person in charge of the research study or the sponsor can remove you from the research study without your
approval if you are found to be ineligible for the study after submitting a questionnaire. What else do I need to know? This research is an initiative developed by players, for players. It began in 2014 in part through an award from the
National Football League Players Association (NFLPA). The Study largely utilizes funds allocated for the research by
the collective bargaining agreement with the NFL. Multiple Harvard- affiliated institutions are also sharing the cost
of the initiative. The Football Players Health Study includes many research studies. We may combine the information collected from you during this study with results from other Football Players Health Study research studies that you have been involved in. Your information may also be connected to any future Football Players Health Study projects that you are a part of. This includes studies that may be done by other researchers who work with the Football Players Health Study. We do not know how many future studies we will have, but there will be many over several years. When you participate in a Football Players Health Study research study, you are agreeing to allow us to collect and store the data from the project for several years. This is useful and important as it allows us to look at changes in health and wellness over time in former football players. We may use information collected from you during this or other Football Players Health Study research studies to determine future research that you may be eligible to participate in. We will use your personal information in order to contact and inform you about these opportunities. Your name and personal information (information that can identify you) are connected to a code that the Football Players Health Study has assigned to you. This code is connected to the data that is collected from you in any Football Players Health Study research study that you participate in (for example, answers to questionnaires, medical history or results of a scan). The key to this code is stored in a secure file that is kept separate from your study data. Only trained members of the Football Players Health Study staff will have access to the key to this code. All of your personal information is stored in a secure database at Harvard separately from the study results. The Football Players Health Study works with other local researchers or researchers in other states or countries. If a researcher wants to use data from the Football Players Health Study, they must make a request in writing describing what type of research they want to do and what type of information they need. These proposals will be reviewed and approved by a committee of Football Players Health Study researchers. In most cases, we will share information that is assigned a code and the researcher will not receive any information that can identify you. There will be occasions that a researcher working with us will require access to your personal information. For example, if we are working with a researcher who is doing in-person research, they may need your name and contact information to make arrangements for you to come for the study. In such cases, we will not share the information without first contacting you to see if you are interested in the specific study and to get your permission to share your personal information. Statement of Consent I have read the information in this consent form including risks and possible benefits. All my questions about the
research have been answered to my satisfaction. I understand that I am free to withdraw at any time without penalty
or loss of benefits to which I am otherwise entitled. I consent to participate in the study Follow the link below to download a copy of this consent form.
Get in the game!
Press "Next Page" to continue on to the "Demographics and Playing History" questionnaire!

Demographic Information and Playing History
Our study team wants to understand how a career in football affects your overall health and quality of life, especially
over time. In order to do this, we need to learn more about what makes you the person you are today. This section will
collect information about your playing history before, during, and after the start of your professional football career. This section will also ask about your life after you stopped playing professional football. Please provide answers for the following questions as best as you are able to recall. Note that in some questions we try
to separate pre-professional and professional play as you may have participated in different activities during those times.

field_label:
Cardiovascular Health Heart health is an important component of overall health, especially for former elite athletes whose hearts may go from different levels of fitness over time. Changes in weight, exercise regimens, and medications also affect heart health. In addition to those factors, this section gathers information on heart surgeries and medications to gain a better understanding of your heart health.

field_label:
Pain Outcomes As we learned through the first questionnaire, pain is one of the most common health complaints experienced by former professional football players. This section will ask about locations and severity of pain, as well as the effect of pain on quality of life. Finally, this section inquires about current and past medication use and surgeries.
  • Demographics and Playing History
  • Cardiovascular Health
  • Neurocognitive Health
  • Pain Outcomes - Up Next!
  • Other Health Outcomes

Press "Next Page" to continue on to the "Pain Outcomes" questionnaire!
Want to take a time out?

Press "Save and Return Later" to receive your "Access code" you'll need this to get back in the survey. Our team can provide it to you if you misplace it. Just contact us at players@footballplayershealth.harvard.edu or at (617) 432-5000. Bookmark the link under your "Access Code", or return through the link in your e-mail. Once you're ready to get back
in the game, open the link and enter the "Access Code" to pick up where you left off. Please do not press 'Start Over' unless you want to restart the survey.
Click here to download the consent form.

Other Health Outcomes Other important aspects of health not included in previous sections are explored here. This section includes diagnoses
of other health conditions and asks about alternative health practices. Additionally, questions about family history are
used to explore genetic factors of disease. Residential history is also included in this section, as recent studies have indicated that place of residence is an important factor for health outcomes. Finally, things that happen in childhood sometimes affect our health as adults. Questions at the end of the survey ask about experiences during your first
18 years of life.
